messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Computable bounds for the reach and ùëü-convexity of subsets of ‚Ñù^ùëë

Paper Abstract: Abstract The convexity of a set can be generalized to the two weaker notions of reach and rùëür-convexity; both describe the regularity of a set‚Äôs boundary. For any compact subset of ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, we provide methods for computing upper bounds on these quantities from point cloud data. The bounds converge to the respective quantities as the point cloud becomes dense in the set, and the rate of convergence for the bound on the reach is given under a weak regularity condition. We also introduce the Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-reach, a generalization of the reach that excludes small-scale features of size less than a parameter Œ≤‚àà[0,‚àû)ùõΩ0\beta\in[0,\infty). Numerical studies suggest how the Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-reach can be used in high-dimension to infer the reach and other geometric properties of smooth submanifolds.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Optimal reach estimation and metric learning",
        "Estimating the reach of a manifold",
        "Nonasymptotic rates for manifold, tangent space and curvature estimation",
        "Estimation of surface area",
        "Random fields and geometry",
        "Geometry-driven collapses for converting a ƒåech complex into a triangulation of a nicely triangulable shape",
        "Vietoris‚Äìrips complexes also provide topologically correct reconstructions of sampled shapes",
        "Surface reconstruction from point clouds by learning predictive context priors",
        "Ripser: efficient computation of Vietoris-Rips persistence barcodes",
        "Estimating the Reach of a Manifold via its Convexity Defect Function",
        "A multivariate uniformity test for the case of unknown support",
        "The effect of discretization on the mean geometry of a 2D random field",
        "Lipschitz-Killing curvatures of excursion sets for two-dimensional random fields",
        "A transformation for extracting new descriptions of shape",
        "Incremental construction of the delaunay triangulation and the delaunay graph in medium dimension",
        "The reach, metric distortion, geodesic convexity and the variation of tangent spaces",
        "Locally uniform anisotropic meshing",
        "A Sampling Theory for Compact Sets in Euclidean Space",
        "Shape Smoothing Using Double Offset",
        "Stability of curvature measures",
        "The ‚ÄúŒªùúÜ\\lambda-medial axis‚Äù",
        "Weak feature size and persistent homology: Computing homology of solids in rn from noisy data samples",
        "Smooth manifold reconstruction from noisy and non-uniform approximation with guarantees",
        "A counter example on a borsuk conjecture",
        "Universally consistent estimation of the reach",
        "Proximal Smoothness and the Lower-C2superscriptùê∂2C^{2} Property",
        "Geometric and isoperimetric properties of sets of positive reach in ùêÑdsuperscriptùêÑùëë\\mathbf{E}^{d}",
        "Surface area and volume of excursion sets observed on point cloud based polytopic tessellations",
        "On the perimeter estimation of pixelated excursion sets of 2D anisotropic random fields",
        "Set estimation: Another bridge between statistics and geometry",
        "A nonparametric approach to the estimation of lengths and surface areas",
        "On Statistical Properties of Sets Fulfilling Rolling-Type Conditions",
        "On the estimation of the medial axis and inner parallel body",
        "On Boundary Estimation",
        "Normal and feature approximations from noisy point clouds",
        "Approximating the Medial Axis from the Voronoi Diagram with a Convergence Guarantee",
        "Minimax adaptive estimation in manifold inference",
        "Geometry and Topology for Mesh Generation",
        "Curvature measures",
        "Homotopy reconstruction via the cech complex and the vietoris-rips complex",
        "Any open bounded subset of ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\\mathbb{R}^{n} has the same homotopy type as its medial axis",
        "Hausdorff and gromov-hausdorff stable subsets of the medial axis",
        "Characterizations of Convex Sets",
        "Finding the Homology of Submanifolds with High Confidence from Random Samples",
        "Set estimation under convexity type restrictions",
        "Sur les ensembles œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon-convexes",
        "Local Differentiability of Distance Functions",
        "Sets with positive reach",
        "A fully data-driven method for estimating the shape of a point cloud",
        "Image Analysis and Mathematical Morphology",
        "PyVista: 3D plotting and mesh analysis through a streamlined interface for the Visualization Toolkit (VTK)",
        "50 years sets with positive reach‚Äîa survey",
        "On a Generalization of Blaschke‚Äôs Rolling Theorem and the Smoothing of Surfaces"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Computable bounds for the reach and ùëü-convexity of subsets of ‚Ñù^ùëë, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
